comments.author: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com
comments.text:
(I have difficulty imagining this isn't already filed, but I can't seem to find it.)

I have http://docs.python.org/library/index.html in my awesomebar history.  When I type that URL, Firefox displays

  "The Python Standard Library -- Python v2.6.5 documentation"

as the title.  But the page's actual title reflects the current version of Python:

  "The Python Standard Library -- Python v2.7.1 documentation"

When I visit a page and its title is different from what Places has stored, Places should update its stored title.
comments.raw_text:
(I have difficulty imagining this isn't already filed, but I can't seem to find it.)

I have http://docs.python.org/library/index.html in my awesomebar history.  When I type that URL, Firefox displays

  "The Python Standard Library -- Python v2.6.5 documentation"

as the title.  But the page's actual title reflects the current version of Python:

  "The Python Standard Library -- Python v2.7.1 documentation"

When I visit a page and its title is different from what Places has stored, Places should update its stored title.
comments.creator: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com

comments.author: sdwilsh@forerunnerdesigns.com
comments.text:
(In reply to comment #2)
> Aha, yes.  Didn't notice that.
Then this is likely the intended behavior.  We'll always show the bookmark title over the page title because the bookmark title is user-set.
comments.raw_text:
(In reply to comment #2)
> Aha, yes.  Didn't notice that.
Then this is likely the intended behavior.  We'll always show the bookmark title over the page title because the bookmark title is user-set.
comments.creator: sdwilsh@forerunnerdesigns.com

comments.author: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com
comments.text:
The bookmark title is user-settable, but in this case, it was not user-set.  I imagine that's the common case.

Perhaps Places should be aware of whether the title was *actually* set by the user.
comments.raw_text:
The bookmark title is user-settable, but in this case, it was not user-set.  I imagine that's the common case.

Perhaps Places should be aware of whether the title was *actually* set by the user.
comments.creator: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com

comments.text: I think we should change all of our titles management in a next schema, since it's insane.  Btw, it's hard to figure out if the user changed the title or not, since the API calls are the same, the backend API just knows someone asked to add a bookmark with a certain title, we could guess that if the bookmark and history titles are the same user didn't change it, at last.
comments.raw_text: I think we should change all of our titles management in a next schema, since it's insane.  Btw, it's hard to figure out if the user changed the title or not, since the API calls are the same, the backend API just knows someone asked to add a bookmark with a certain title, we could guess that if the bookmark and history titles are the same user didn't change it, at last.
comments.creator: mak@mozilla.com
comments.author: mak@mozilla.com

comments.text: let's transform the bug, I can't find the dupe for now, even if I recall previous bugs about this, will dupe in future in case.

comments.author: mak@mozilla.com
brian@briansmith.org
comments.text: Use case: I bookmark a bug. Then the bug's summary changes. All my email for this bug has the new summary in the subject, but the awesomebar always retains the old summary. This happens to me all the time.
comments.raw_text: Use case: I bookmark a bug. Then the bug's summary changes. All my email for this bug has the new summary in the subject, but the awesomebar always retains the old summary. This happens to me all the time.
comments.creator: brian@briansmith.org
